HTML

Introduction

HTML (Hyper Text Markup Language) is the standard markup language and is used to describe the structure of web pages. HTML elements are represented by tags and are the building blocks of HTML pages. Browsers do not display the HTML tags, but use them to render the content of the page.

HTML files should have the .html file extension.

A very basic HTML document can be found below:

                        

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang='en'>
<head>
    <meta charset='utf-8' />
    <title>Page Title</title>
</head>
<body>

<h1>Heading</h1>
<p>A very simple paragraph.</p>

</body>
</html>

Comments

Comment tags are used to insert comments in your HTML code. Comments are not displayed by the browser, but they can help document your HTML source code. Comments can also be used for debugging because you can comment out HTML code to search for errors.

                        

<!-- This is a comment in HTML -->

<!-- Do not display this
<p>A very simple paragraph.</p>
-->

Headings

Headings are defined with the <h1> to <h6> tags. <h1> defines the most important heading, <h6> defines the least important heading.

<h1> should always be the first heading on any page, followed by <h2>, <h3> etc. Search engines use the headings to index the structure and content of your web pages. Headings are important in showing the document structure. Headings should only be used for headings and not to make text large or bold.

Browsers automatically add some margin before and after a heading.

                        

<h1>Heading 1</h1>
<h2>Heading 2</h2>
<h3>Heading 3</h3>
<h4>Heading 4</h4>
<h5>Heading 5</h5>
<h6>Heading 6</h6>

Links

The following examples demonstrate how to apply a link to HTML.

Further details can also be found here.

                        

<a href='https://www.google.com'>Google</a>
<a href='page2.html'>Link to page2</a>

<!-- Open in a new tab/window -->
<a href='#' target='_blank'>Open in a new tab/window</a>

<!-- Open in a new tab/window with added security -->
<a href='#' target='_blank' rel='noopener noreferrer'>Link</a>

HTML Elements & Tags

HTML tags are element names surrounded by brackets. Tags normally come in pairs, like <p> and </p>. The first tag is called the start/opening tag, and the end tag is called the end/closing tag.

An HTML element usually consists of a start tag and end tag, with the content inserted between. The HTML element is everything from the start tag to the end tag.

HTML elements with no content are called empty element. These elements have no end tag, such as the <br> element.

                        

<tag>Content goes here.</tag>

<p>A very simple paragraph.</p>

<!-- Empty HTML element -->
<br>

HTML Attributes

Attributes provide additional information about an HTML element. All HTML elements can have attributes and they are always specified in the start/opening tag. You can apply more than one attribute to HTML elements if required.

Further information can be found here.

                        

<!-- Link without the href attribute -->
<a>Link</a>
<!-- With href attribute -->
<a href='https://www.website.com'>Link</a>

<!-- div element without any attributes -->
<div>Content here</div>
<!-- div element with class attribute -->
<div class='bold'>Content here</div>
<!-- div element with id attribute -->
<div id='blockOne'>Content here</div>
<!-- div element with multiple attributes -->
<div class='bold border' id='blockTwo'>Content here</div>

When applying JavaScript to HTML elements, it is recommended to use attributes with a 'js-' prefix. This helps separate CSS styling and JavaScript functionality in HTML.

                        

<!-- div element with CSS and JavaScript class attributes -->
<div class='js-function bold'>Content here</div>

HTML Language

The HTML lang attribute can be used to declare the language of a web page or portion of a web page to assist search engines and browsers. You should declare the primary language for each web page in your HTML code using the lang atribute within the <html> tag. In this example, the language has been set to English.

                        

<html lang='en'>

<!-- The page is in the British style of English -->
<html lang='en-GB'>
<!-- The page is in the US style of English -->
<html lang='en-US'>

File Paths

A file path describes the location of a file. File paths are used when linking to an external files such as: pages, images, stylesheets, and scripts.

An absolute path is usually a web address/URL. A relative path points to a file relative to the current page.

It is best practice to use relative file paths where possible. Your pages will not be bound to your current base URL and all links will work on your local environment as well as current or future public domains.

                        

<!-- Absolute path: URL -->
<img src='https://www.website.com/images/picture.jpg' alt='Mountain' />

<!-- Relative path -->
<img src='/images/picture.jpg' alt='Mountain' />

<!-- Points to folder located one level above current folder -->
<img src='../images/picture.jpg' alt='Mountain' />

HTML Entities

Some characters are reserved in HTML. For example, if you use the less than (<) or greater than (>) signs in your text, the browser may mistake them for HTML tags. Character entities are used to display reserver characters in HTML. These are sometimes known as special characters.

                        

&entity_name;   // e.g. &lt;
